messages.text: Considering how fast Julia is, it's disappointing that it lacks a lot of functionality for eliding allocations: No reading each line into a buffer, no string splitting without allocations, `map` and `filter` is eager, AFAIK there is no mutable `AbstractString` , etc.

messages.text: Google presenting olddddd documentation versions of Julia packages as the top result. It feels like the internet is gaslighting you sometimes. (<@U69BL50BF> in this case, top result for "julia DiffEq" links to v2.0 of the docs) Second result fortunately is correct, but I can't help but think how many new-to-Julia people are less impressed by the docs from nearly 4 years ago....!

messages.text: It is agonizing (and somewhat amusing) that Julia doesn't have `rref` built into Base.LinearAlgebra at the moment and that it was removed ~5 years ago (if I can count right). It definitely spoils the experience of using Julia for some quick linalg calculations.

messages.text:
Am I timing TTFP wrong?
Julia 1.0
```
julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 23.029167 seconds (52.21 M allocations: 2.723 GiB, 5.60% gc time)```
Julia 1.6
```
julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 20.384380 seconds (60.73 M allocations: 3.559 GiB, 6.93% gc time)```
Like technically it is better.
But not by much?

messages.text:
Julia Syndrome :sneezing_face:-- _worrying about the performance of one's app before one even starts seeing problems._
Terminal Pre-Julia Syndrome :skull:-- _worrying about the performance of one's app so badly that one never gets around to writing it._

elements.text: worrying about the performance of one's app before one even starts seeing problems.
worrying about the performance of one's app so badly that one never gets around to writing it.

messages.text: I do this way too much.  It's part of my more general problem with excessive planning getting in the way of ever actually doing anything.  Spend so much time thinking about how to make the initial implementation of something absolutely perfect that I just never do it

elements.text: I do this way too much.  It's part of my more general problem with excessive planning getting in the way of ever actually doing anything.  Spend so much time thinking about how to make the initial implementation of something absolutely perfect that I just never do it

messages.text:
One way to getting around this I find is to not stress too much about having to re-write parts of your code.

Step 1: Write your code to the best of your ability.
Step 2: Benchmark, does it need optimizing?
Step 3: Optimize if optimization is needed.

More often than not, getting a working program up and running is more valuable than being meticulous with performance gains.

elements.text:

messages.text:
```function float2rational(x::T) where T
    iszero(x) && return 0//1
    isfinite(x) || return x
    e = exponent(x)
    m = Base.significand_bits(T)
    b = Base.exponent_bias(T)
    issub = issubnormal(x)
    expo = (issub ? 1-b : e) - m
    ee = expo >= 0 ? (big(2)^expo)//1 : 1//(big(2)^(-expo))
    ss = reinterpret(Unsigned, x) & Base.significand_mask(T)
    issub || (ss = ss | (1 << m))
    dec = ss * ee
    signbit(x) ? -dec : dec
end```
This might work?

elements.text:
function float2rational(x::T) where T
    iszero(x) && return 0//1
    isfinite(x) || return x
    e = exponent(x)
    m = Base.significand_bits(T)
    b = Base.exponent_bias(T)
    issub = issubnormal(x)
    expo = (issub ? 1-b : e) - m
    ee = expo >= 0 ? (big(2)^expo)//1 : 1//(big(2)^(-expo))
    ss = reinterpret(Unsigned, x) & Base.significand_mask(T)
    issub || (ss = ss | (1 << m))
    dec = ss * ee
    signbit(x) ? -dec : dec
end

messages.text: How DifferentialEquations.jl started. *Prof*: I only teach MATLAB, here's a finite element toolbox to use in your homework. *Me*: I want to try out Julia, and just using a library means I won't learn very much? *Prof*: So just try to build the library while doing the homework and see if you can match my speed because there's a lot of tricks I teach and did. *My Homework*: How to accelerate PDE solving 10x over this MATLAB toolbox (the blog posts are still up :slightly_smiling_face:).

messages.text: Me. Second year phd. try to experiment with neural networks for quantum physics. Get started in Python. Tensorflow? I don’t get it. Try numpy. Too slow. Let’s go to C++. Can’t get any work done. Matlab? I won’t even try. Julia seems perfect for that. End result: publish. Take credit

messages.text: I got into Julia because I was tired of debugging a custom Matlab class’s `subsref` function.  It was — kid you not — 2708 lines of code and still couldn’t appropriately act like an array.  That’s how the `AbstractArray` “interface” came to be.

messages.text:
I banged my head so hard against Python/Numpy trying to implement efficient nucleotide k-mer counting that I almost got brain damage and went for C++. When I in my frustration discovered Julia, I learned it by re-implementing BioSymbols.jl and BioSequences, then made a PR to re-implement BioSequence's k-mer iteration.
Also, has this turned into Julia <#C6FGJ8REC|appreciation>?

Back to gripes:
It would be great to get a collection of these “origin stories” and put them on <http://julialang.org|julialang.org>

elements.text: It would be great to get a collection of these “origin stories” and put them on

messages.text:
Assorted MATLAB gripes:
- MATLAB's Neural Net Toolbox used to overwrite the activation function with sigmoid, no matter what you passed in. To get that bug fix we would need to pay for the new version of the Toolbox, for everyone.
- Can't mutate arrays in functions. _Sometimes_ the compiler is smart enough to avoid allocation if you pass the array in and assign to it.
- You can have nested functions but you can't use them to mutate any variables they capture. BUT you can always mutate any variables in any part of the call stack using `workspace`.
- Everything about dates pre-2014.
- Every time you call a function in a C library you have to write a MEX function, no shortcuts.
- You want to run two things in parallel? That costs extra!
- Dates as floating point numbers? What could _possibly_ go wrong??
- Mathworks in 2007: no one should ever need to add two 64-bit integers (never mind that C99 had this).
- At least 3 different argument parsing functions, all in proprietary toolboxes and all different.
- Arbitrary conventions around matrix reductions ("vectors" behave different from "matrixes" despite both being matrixes).
- We had used a standard plot function that could plot dates on an axis, when provided as datevecs (Mx3 matrix, with Y,M,D). If you provided exactly 3 datevecs it would assume you were giving it a color map.
- `for` loops iterate over columns because fuck you.
- `length` gives the length of the longest dimension.
- dispatch by file/folder name.

messages.text: :grapes: Packages with too many tests. Don't get me wrong, of course I'm a fan of good test coverage. It's just, if you have 25.000 tests to cover 1000 lines of code, maybe cut it down.

elements.text: Packages with too many tests. Don't get me wrong, of course I'm a fan of good test coverage. It's just, if you have 25.000 tests to cover 1000 lines of code, maybe cut it down.

messages.text: I hope that some day most of the issues with connecting to servers and downloading things will be sorted out. The first step was using libcurl everywhere, so at least we do the same thing everywhere. But now there’s the long process of stomping out problems that various people have

messages.text: I was working on this project and was just about to run this R code that I wrote that would parse ~ million files and extract some info form them. I left the script running on a remote machine and run off to catch my train. When I sshed to the machine 30 minutes later, it was still running. Out of boredom, I rewrote the logic in julia and to my amazement, it finished in 20 seconds. So I cancelled the R job and started reading the Julia docs...

Out of boredom, I rewrote the logic in julia and to my amazement, it finished in 20 seconds. So I cancelled the R job and started reading the Julia docs...

messages.text: `Cchar === Int8`, but `IOBuffer` expecting `Array{UInt8, 1}`.

What's happening here?
```julia> any((==).('a'), "abc")
true

julia> all((==).('a'), "abc")
false

julia> any((==).('a'), "")
false

julia> all((==).('a'), "")
true```

elements.text:
julia> any((==).('a'), "abc")
true

julia> all((==).('a'), "abc")
false

julia> any((==).('a'), "")
false

julia> all((==).('a'), "")
true

messages.text: There is a significant delay (at least several hours - this is what I observe, is this expected?) till servers that provide packages update their registry to newly tagged version of the package. This significantly complicates joint development of packages that depend on each other. The only solution I have found is to checkout `main` branch.

I wish there was a way to add to deprecation warnings an extra note.
Particularly to highlight that while the listed code will give identical behavour to before, most of the time you should do this other code.

ChainRulesTestUtils just made the majority of its arguments optional with good defaults that just work.
Sometimes there are good reasons to override those defaults but 99% of code can just delete those inputs and rely on the defaults instead.

I am still frustrated that we don’t have either: the julia version stored in the Manifest.toml
Or `Manifest.1_0_5.toml` , `Manifest.1_5_3.toml` , etc.
it is so annoying that if I want to version control  a Manifest for a application that I want to know we are making conscious changes to the versions, that if someone mistakenly checks in a Manifest generated with 1.6, then CI running julia 1.5 will explode with a confusing error message.
(and there is no way at all that i can make CI work for multiple julia versions using Manifests)

example of where i want to version control a Manifest:
<https://github.com/JuliaDiff/juliadiff.github.io/pull/14>

messages.text:
Argh. Get an excel sheet with 2 columns of 40 numbers (grades). “My my, they look correlated - let me have  a look. Let me just open Julia”. Open REPL, walk slowly to the folder,  open Pluto, new notebook - open the notebook takes like a full minute, and I’m starting to forget what I wanted to see. `using StatsPlots` - error saying “try `]instantiate`“. Turns out `]` doesn’t work in Pluto. In fact, Pkg operations don’t really work in Pluto. Instantiate has no effect. Open a new REPL, instantiate, status, resolve, no issues. `using StatsPlots` in REPL no issue. Open Pluto again, `using StatsPlots`- error saying “try `]instantiate`“. Open Excel and do the work I wanted to do there.
For all it’s beauty, Julia really isn’t very nice for quick stuff.

messages.text:
It is interposing its autoself between my desire to give aor get help and pleasantness.
To be the first response to every new posting by all posters is too heavy a hand.
MOST CRITICALLY: this has made our slack a less welcoming experience and that
      _plays against the so very many individual efforts that shape the Julia Community_

messages.text:
I'm still thinking about two suggestions:
(1) Implementing an active option. I.e. you "summon" it deliberately if someone thinks the thread may be worthwhile
(2) Only threads of a certain length are considered by default. E.g. after 5-10 answers the bot jumps in and asks because this is likely to be an interesting topic

messages.text:
I keep getting annoyed that `eltype(map(f, vector))` isn't deterministic. We've got nullable data the output (or it's eltype) will be used in dispatch or other logic elsewhere - and when `Union{T, Nothing}` becomes `Nothing` or `Union{T, Missing}` becomes `Missing`  then we loose all the semantic information that `T` tells us. We can fix it up with `T[f(x) for x in vector]` or similar, having determined the correct output `T` manually ourselves, but honestly it seems better to me in basically all cases I use it if the output type of `map` was determined solely from the type of the inputs rather than the values.

Does anyone else feel this way? Or is there something people find particularly useful about the current value-based semantics?

elements.text: isn't deterministic. We've got nullable data the output (or it's eltype) will be used in dispatch or other logic elsewhere - and when
then we loose all the semantic information that
tells us. We can fix it up with

manually ourselves, but honestly it seems better to me in basically all cases I use it if the output type of

was determined solely from the type of the inputs rather than the values.

Does anyone else feel this way? Or is there something people find particularly useful about the current value-based semantics?

messages.text:
```julia> eltype(map(sin, Any[1, 2, π]))
Float64```
is a nice property to have

elements.text: is a nice property to have

messages.text: Rather than getting back `Any`
(unless I'm misunderstanding the gripe)

Yes that's probably the one case it is helpful - some automatic narrowing from `Any`. It doesn't really come up for me unless I'm scripting, though. You can always use `collect` when you want to narrow, however, like
```v = Any[1, 2, π]
map(sin, collect(v))```
I'd say the workaround here is a lot easier than the workaround I've resorted to above.

when you want to narrow, however, like

messages.text: I believe this boils down to a question about to what extent type inference should affect the semantics of julia, versus just playing a role in improving performance. For the empty-collection case, there are no values to query, and so either there's some type inference, or it's always `Any`.

elements.text: I believe this boils down to a question about to what extent type inference should affect the semantics of julia, versus just playing a role in improving performance. For the empty-collection case, there are no values to query, and so either there's some type inference, or it's always

messages.text:
In my opinion, this is a big wart:

```julia
julia> f(x) = ifelse(iseven(x), "even", :odd)
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> map(f, 1:2)
2-element Vector{Any}:
 :odd
 "even"

julia> map(f, 1:1)
1-element Vector{Symbol}:
 :odd

julia> map(f, 1:0)
Union{String, Symbol}[]```

elements.text: In my opinion, this is a big wart:

julia
julia> f(x) = ifelse(iseven(x), "even", :odd)
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> map(f, 1:2)
2-element Vector{Any}:
 :odd
 "even"

julia> map(f, 1:1)
1-element Vector{Symbol}:
 :odd

julia> map(f, 1:0)
Union{String, Symbol}[]

messages.text:
I wonder if you can elaborate on how losing that a `nothing` corresponds to not-a-`T` causes an issue down the line? I don't doubt it's an issue, but I'd like to see an example if you have one handy.

There's some (core-to-julia) sense in which functions are supposed to be generic, and so any methods defined for specific types should be conceptually related to any other method. Is there a function with e.g. a method for  `Vector{Nothing}` and a method for `Vector{Union{T, Nothing}}` and these methods "mean" different things?

messages.text:
In any case, this is my guess for what happened in a nutshell:

```julia> average(v::Vector{<:Union{Nothing, Float64}}) = :mean
average (generic function with 1 method)

julia> average(v::Vector{<:Union{Nothing, String}}) = :mode
average (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> average([1.0, 2.0])
:mean

julia> average([1.0, 2.0, nothing])
:mean

julia> average([""])
:mode

julia> average(["", nothing])
:mode

julia> average([nothing])
ERROR: MethodError: average(::Vector{Nothing}) is ambiguous. Candidates:
  average(v::Vector{var"#s24"} where var"#s24"<:Union{Nothing, Float64}) in Main at REPL[21]:1
  average(v::Vector{var"#s24"} where var"#s24"<:Union{Nothing, String}) in Main at REPL[22]:1```

root.text:
I keep getting annoyed that `eltype(map(f, vector))` isn't deterministic. We've got nullable data the output (or it's eltype) will be used in dispatch or other logic elsewhere - and when `Union{T, Nothing}` becomes `Nothing` or `Union{T, Missing}` becomes `Missing`  then we loose all the semantic information that `T` tells us. We can fix it up with `T[f(x) for x in vector]` or similar, having determined the correct output `T` manually ourselves, but honestly it seems better to me in basically all cases I use it if the output type of `map` was determined solely from the type of the inputs rather than the values.

Does anyone else feel this way? Or is there something people find particularly useful about the current value-based semantics?

elements.text: isn't deterministic. We've got nullable data the output (or it's eltype) will be used in dispatch or other logic elsewhere - and when
then we loose all the semantic information that
tells us. We can fix it up with
or similar, having determined the correct output
manually ourselves, but honestly it seems better to me in basically all cases I use it if the output type of

was determined solely from the type of the inputs rather than the values.

Does anyone else feel this way? Or is there something people find particularly useful about the current value-based semantics?
In any case, this is my guess for what happened in a nutshell:

julia> average(v::Vector{<:Union{Nothing, Float64}}) = :mean
average (generic function with 1 method)

julia> average(v::Vector{<:Union{Nothing, String}}) = :mode
average (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> average([1.0, 2.0])
:mean

julia> average([1.0, 2.0, nothing])
:mean

julia> average([""])
:mode

julia> average(["", nothing])
:mode

julia> average([nothing])
ERROR: MethodError: average(::Vector{Nothing}) is ambiguous. Candidates:
  average(v::Vector{var"#s24"} where var"#s24"<:Union{Nothing, Float64}) in Main at REPL[21]:1
  average(v::Vector{var"#s24"} where var"#s24"<:Union{Nothing, String}) in Main at REPL[22]:1

messages.text: Yeah - thanks. Perhaps that would be a good use-case for us (we typically have to treat the null value differently anyway so it wouldn't add tonnes of overhead).

messages.text:
I bet this has been hashed out to some extent in: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/22682>

and perhaps this example should be mentioned at <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/types/#Type-Unions> since `Union{Nothing, T}` is really not a perfect replacement for "Maybe{T}".

messages.text: If I may self-advertise a bit, I made ErrorTypes.jl for exactly that, and use it in my own code. It's built on Mason's SumTypes, and is intended to ape Rust's Result and Option.

elements.text: If I may self-advertise a bit, I made ErrorTypes.jl for exactly that, and use it in my own code. It's built on Mason's SumTypes, and is intended to ape Rust's Result and Option.

messages.text:
```ERROR: MethodError: no method matching Array{Float64, 1}(::Vector{Float64})```
When the literal `1` is a `Int64` on a 32bit julia version.
This happens when reconstructing type signatures from JLD2 files
<https://github.com/JuliaIO/JLD2.jl/issues/281>

elements.text: ERROR: MethodError: no method matching Array{Float64, 1}(::Vector{Float64})

on a 32bit julia version.
This happens when reconstructing type signatures from JLD2 files

messages.text:
We need to do more to educate people about not tagging breaking changes for not breaking things.
Not to pick on Lasso in particular, but it is such an example of this.
<https://github.com/JuliaStats/Lasso.jl/releases>
v0.6.0 not only had no breaking changes, it had no user facing API changes at all.
It had an improved docstring, and a change to the tests, and changed the compat
